conclusion: The mover accelerates due to the electromagnetic force (Lorentz force) when current flows through the coil.
The force on the coil is given by F_mag = nI B l.
n = 100 is the number of turns, I is the current, B = 0.1 T is the magnetic flux density, l = 1 m is the length of each turn.
From t = 0 to t = t_1, the mover accelerates to the takeoff speed v_1 = 80 m/s.
Using Newton's second law: F_mag = (M + m) a.
M = 10 kg is the mass of the aircraft, m = 5 kg is the mass of the mover and coil, a is the acceleration.
The total mass is M + m = 15 kg.
The velocity-time graph indicates a uniform acceleration phase from 0 to t_1 = 1.5 s.
Acceleration a is calculated as a = v_1 / t_1 = 80 m/s / 1.5 s ≈ 53.33 m/s^2.
Using F_mag = (M + m) a, nI B l = (M + m) a.
The current I of the constant current source is I = 80 A.
